item.title: CONSTRUCTION OF SHEDS, AND PREPARATION OF PRESSING-PLACE AND HEARTHS (DHISHNYAS).
item.description: 01 The sacrifice is a man; it is a man for the reason that a man spreads (prepares) it. In being spread it is made just as large 1 as a man: this is why the sacrifice is a man. 02 The Soma-cart (shed) is no other than his head, and has Vishṇu for its deity 2. And because Soma is therein–Soma being havis (material for offering) for the gods–therefore it is called Havirdhāna (receptacle of havis).

item.title: PREPARATION OF THE SOMA ALTAR WITH THE HIGH ALTARxa0[^fn_290].
item.description: 01 From that post which is the largest on the east side (of the hall) 1 he now strides three steps forwards (to the east), and there drives in a peg,–this is the intermediate (peg) 2. 02 From that middle peg he strides fifteen steps to the right, and there drives in a peg,–this is the right hip. 03 From that middle peg he strides fifteen steps northwards, and there drives in a peg,–this is the left hip.

item.title: THE AGNI-PRANAYANA, OR LEADING FORWARD OF THE FIRExa0[^fn_321] TO THE HIGH ALTAR.
item.description: 01 They put fire-wood on (the Āhavanīya fire), and prepare the underlayer (of gravel 1). He (the Adhvaryu) puts the butter on (the Gārhapatya to melt), and cleans both the dipping-spoon and the offering-spoon. Having then clarified the ghee, he ladles five times thereof (into the offering-spoon). When the fire-wood is ablaze- 02 They lift the (burning) fire-wood, and place it on the underlayer 2. Thereupon he says (to the Hotr̥), ‘Recite for Agni as he is taken forward 3!

item.title: UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: 01 It is for a twofold reason that the sounding-holes are dug. The cart-shed, truly, is the head of the sacrificer; and what four holes there are here in the head–namely, these two and these two 1–those he thereby makes: for this reason he digs the sounding-holes. 02 Now the gods and the Asuras, both of them sprung from Prajāpati, were contending. The Asuras then by way of witchcraft buried charms 2 within these worlds, thinking, ‘Peradventure we may thus overcome the gods.
